project.name: Form Functionality Library
project.description: A scalable, testable, and modular form library that integrates into Webflow's native form builder.

instructions.usage: This project builds a functionality library for Webflow forms. It is designed to be used in conjunction with the Webflow form builder, and must be modular, lightweight and easy to implement in Webflow. Elements and funcitonality are bound via data-attributes.

notes.note: This library is designed to be used in conjunction with the Webflow form builder. It is not designed to be used as a standalone form library. It leverages data-attributes to bind elements and functionality and must be modular, lightweight and easily integratable into any webflow form that uses a multi-step or single step form.

The form wrapper must have a data-form attribute that is set to "multistep" or "single-step". Multi-step forms will utilize the multi-step module, and summary modules. Single-step forms will still need access to validation, form-field formatting.
The form wrapper must have a data-form="multistep" attribute and a data-logic="true" attribute.
1. multi-step navigation uses data-go-to and data-answer attributes.to navigate to a step, set data-go-to to the step id. To answer a step, set data-answer to the step id.
2. Multi-step navigation is executed when a user uses either data-form="next-btn" or data-form="prev-btn", or data-form="skip-btn".
3. All inputs are saved into the browser's local storage until form has successfullly been submitted.

4. Each form field has a "data-form-field" attribute that is used to identify the field. This is used to save the field's value to local storage and is bound to "data-summary-field" which is used to display the field's value in the summary.
5. Branching logic, when one option is selected, the form will navitate to that next step, and disable other branch option field validation.

6. Form field formatting must be handled by a form-field module that provides uniform structure across all form types (single-step, multi-step, etc.). All form fields follow this standardized base structure: Base HTML Structure:
<[input-element] class="form_input w-input" data-step-field-name="fieldName">
Error text
Where [input-element] can be: - for text inputs - for dropdowns - for text areas - for selection inputs This base structure remains consistent regardless of input complexity. Child elements within the wrapper can have additional classes, IDs, nested structures (icons, validation hints, etc.) for unique modifications, but the core wrapper ‚Üí label ‚Üí input ‚Üí error pattern is uniform across all implementations.
